newsitem.title: USA: Discount chain Target stops selling cigarettes.
newsitem.headline: Discount chain Target stops selling cigarettes.

text.p: Discount store giant Target, citing rising costs of carrying tabacco products, said Wednesday it will stop selling cigarettes in its 714 stores by the end of next month.

Target, the nation's third-largest discount store chain, said the expense of complying with local restrictions on cigarette sales and declining profit margins caused it to remove the product from its shelves.
"It's really a business decision," said Susan Eich, a spokeswoman for Target, which is a unit of Dayton Hudson Corp .
"Obviously a lot of people are going to be happy or unhappy about this, regardless of the rationale," she said.
Stores that Target has opened during the last year, or about 20 percent of the chain, do not carry cigarettes, she said.
Cigarettes make up less than a half of one percentage point of Target's annual sales. "Volume per store has been declining in recent years," said Eich.
The steep cost of building special counters to control tabacco sales, along with a high theft rate, made it difficult to stick with the product.
Snack foods and sports trading cards will be stocked where cigarettes once were displayed.
Target said it informed distributors of its decision last month. Philip Morris Cos Inc. is the retailer's largest supplier of cigarettes.
